SPROCLIB - Semantic Process Control Library
  • Utilities Package
  • Edit on GitHub

Utilities Package

The utilities package provides essential control design utilities, mathematical tools, and data processing functions for process control applications.

Note

This is part of the modern modular structure of SPROCLIB. For legacy compatibility, see Legacy Package.

Submodules

Control Utils

Control Utilities for SPROCLIB

This module provides utility functions specifically for control system design, tuning, and performance evaluation.

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

utilities.control_utils.tune_pid(model_params: Dict[str, float], method: str = 'ziegler_nichols', controller_type: str = 'PID') → Dict[str, float][source]

Automatic PID tuning using empirical rules.

Parameters:

  • model_params – Process model parameters

  • method – Tuning method (‘ziegler_nichols’, ‘amigo’, ‘lambda_tuning’)

  • controller_type – Controller type (‘P’, ‘PI’, ‘PID’)

Returns:

Dictionary with PID parameters

utilities.control_utils.simulate_process(model: ~typing.Callable, t_span: ~typing.Tuple[float, float], x0: <MagicMock id='1744480651984'>, u_profile: ~typing.Callable[[float], <MagicMock id='1744480652320'>], method: str = 'RK45', max_step: float | None = None) → Dict[str, <MagicMock id='1744480075264'>][source]

Simulate a process model with given input profile.

Parameters:

  • model – Function f(t, x, u) returning dx/dt

  • t_span – Time span (start, end)

  • x0 – Initial conditions

  • u_profile – Function u(t) returning inputs

  • method – Integration method

  • max_step – Maximum step size

Returns:

Dictionary with simulation results

Calculate Integral of Squared Error (ISE).

Parameters:

  • t – Time array

  • error – Error signal array

Returns:

ISE value

Calculate Integral of Absolute Error (IAE).

Parameters:

  • t – Time array

  • error – Error signal array

Returns:

IAE value

utilities.control_utils.calculate_itae(t: <MagicMock id='1744480649296'>, error: <MagicMock id='1744480653328'>) → float[source]

Calculate Integral of Time-weighted Absolute Error (ITAE).

Parameters:

  • t – Time array

  • error – Error signal array

Returns:

ITAE value

utilities.control_utils.design_lead_lag(zero: float, pole: float, gain: float = 1.0) → Tuple[<MagicMock id='1744480653664'>, <MagicMock id='1744480654000'>][source]

Design lead-lag compensator transfer function.

Parameters:

  • zero – Zero location

  • pole – Pole location

  • gain – DC gain

Returns:

Tuple of (numerator, denominator) coefficients

utilities.control_utils.root_locus_design(plant_num: <MagicMock id='1744480655680'>, plant_den: <MagicMock id='1744480656016'>, desired_poles: ~typing.List[complex]) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Design controller using root locus method.

Parameters:

  • plant_num – Plant numerator coefficients

  • plant_den – Plant denominator coefficients

  • desired_poles – Desired closed-loop pole locations

Returns:

Dictionary with controller design results

utilities.control_utils.frequency_domain_design(plant_num: <MagicMock id='1744480656352'>, plant_den: <MagicMock id='1744480656688'>, gain_margin_db: float = 6.0, phase_margin_deg: float = 45.0) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Design controller using frequency domain specifications.

Parameters:

  • plant_num – Plant numerator coefficients

  • plant_den – Plant denominator coefficients

  • gain_margin_db – Desired gain margin [dB]

  • phase_margin_deg – Desired phase margin [degrees]

Returns:

Dictionary with controller design results

utilities.control_utils.step_response_test(data: ~typing.Dict[str, <MagicMock id='1744480657024'>], step_time: float | None = None) → Dict[str, float][source]

Analyze step response test data.

Parameters:

  • data – Dictionary with ‘t’ and ‘y’ arrays

  • step_time – Time when step was applied

Returns:

Dictionary with step response characteristics

utilities.control_utils.linearize(model_func: ~typing.Callable, x_ss: <MagicMock id='1744480658032'>, u_ss: <MagicMock id='1744480658368'>, epsilon: float = 1e-06) → Tuple[<MagicMock id='1744480658704'>, <MagicMock id='1744480659040'>][source]

Linearize a nonlinear model around an operating point.

Parameters:

  • model_func – Function f(x, u) returning dx/dt

  • x_ss – Steady-state states

  • u_ss – Steady-state inputs

  • epsilon – Perturbation size for finite differences

Returns:

A, B matrices for linear model dx/dt = A*x + B*u

utilities.control_utils.disturbance_rejection(plant_tf: ~typing.Tuple[<MagicMock id='1744480660720'>, <MagicMock id='1744480661056'>], controller_tf: ~typing.Tuple[<MagicMock id='1744480662736'>, <MagicMock id='1744480663072'>], disturbance_type: str = 'step', w: <MagicMock id='1744480664752'> | None = None) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Analyze disturbance rejection performance.

Parameters:

  • plant_tf – Plant transfer function (num, den)

  • controller_tf – Controller transfer function (num, den)

  • disturbance_type – Type of disturbance (‘step’, ‘ramp’, ‘frequency’)

  • w – Frequency vector for analysis

Returns:

Dictionary with disturbance rejection analysis

utilities.control_utils.model_predictive_control(A: <MagicMock id='1744481223072'>, B: <MagicMock id='1744481223408'>, Q: <MagicMock id='1744481223744'>, R: <MagicMock id='1744481224080'>, prediction_horizon: int = 10, control_horizon: int | None = None) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Basic Model Predictive Control formulation.

Parameters:

  • A – State-space matrices

  • B – State-space matrices

  • Q – State and input weighting matrices

  • R – State and input weighting matrices

  • prediction_horizon – Prediction horizon N

  • control_horizon – Control horizon M (default: same as prediction horizon)

Returns:

Dictionary with MPC formulation matrices

Math Utils

Math Utilities for SPROCLIB

This module provides mathematical utility functions for process control including signal processing, numerical methods, and mathematical operations.

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

utilities.math_utils.step_response(system, t: <MagicMock id='1744480063168'> | None = None, t_final: float = 10.0, input_magnitude: float = 1.0) → Dict[str, <MagicMock id='1744480064176'>][source]

Calculate step response of a system.

Parameters:

  • system – Transfer function object or (num, den) tuple

  • t – Time vector (optional)

  • t_final – Final time if t not provided

  • input_magnitude – Step magnitude

Returns:

Dictionary with ‘t’ and ‘y’ arrays

utilities.math_utils.bode_plot(system, w: <MagicMock id='1744480065184'> | None = None, plot: bool = True, title: str = 'Bode Plot') → Dict[str, <MagicMock id='1744478583648'>][source]

Generate Bode plot for frequency response analysis.

Parameters:

  • system – Transfer function object or (num, den) tuple

  • w – Frequency vector (optional)

  • plot – Whether to create plot

  • title – Plot title

Returns:

Dictionary with frequency, magnitude, and phase data

utilities.math_utils.linearize(model_func, x_ss: <MagicMock id='1744480059808'>, u_ss: <MagicMock id='1744480060144'>, epsilon: float = 1e-06) → Tuple[<MagicMock id='1744480060480'>, <MagicMock id='1744480060816'>][source]

Linearize a nonlinear model around an operating point.

Parameters:

  • model_func – Function f(x, u) returning dx/dt

  • x_ss – Steady-state states

  • u_ss – Steady-state inputs

  • epsilon – Perturbation size for finite differences

Returns:

A, B matrices for linear model dx/dt = A*x + B*u

Check if a linear system is stable.

Parameters:

A – State matrix

Returns:

True if stable, False otherwise

Routh-Hurwitz stability criterion.

Parameters:

coeffs – Characteristic polynomial coefficients

Returns:

Dictionary with stability analysis

utilities.math_utils.frequency_response(num: <MagicMock id='1744480067872'>, den: <MagicMock id='1744480068208'>, w: <MagicMock id='1744480068544'>) → Tuple[<MagicMock id='1744480068880'>, <MagicMock id='1744480069216'>][source]

Calculate frequency response.

Parameters:

  • num – Numerator coefficients

  • den – Denominator coefficients

  • w – Frequency vector

Returns:

Magnitude and phase arrays

Data Utils

Data Utilities for SPROCLIB

This module provides data processing utilities for process control including filtering, resampling, and data analysis functions.

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

utilities.data_utils.filter_data(data: <MagicMock id='1744480070560'>, filter_type: str = 'lowpass', cutoff: float = 0.1, order: int = 2, method: str = 'butterworth') → <MagicMock id='1744480070896'>[source]

Filter time series data.

Parameters:

  • data – Input data array

  • filter_type – Type of filter (‘lowpass’, ‘highpass’, ‘bandpass’)

  • cutoff – Cutoff frequency (normalized)

  • order – Filter order

  • method – Filter method (‘butterworth’, ‘chebyshev’, ‘bessel’)

Returns:

Filtered data array

utilities.data_utils.resample_data(t: <MagicMock id='1744480071232'>, data: <MagicMock id='1744480071568'>, new_dt: float, method: str = 'linear') → Tuple[<MagicMock id='1744480071904'>, <MagicMock id='1744480072240'>][source]

Resample time series data.

Parameters:

  • t – Original time array

  • data – Original data array

  • new_dt – New sampling interval

  • method – Interpolation method

Returns:

New time array and resampled data

utilities.data_utils.detect_outliers(data: <MagicMock id='1744479157760'>, method: str = 'iqr', threshold: float = 1.5) → <MagicMock id='1744479152384'>[source]

Detect outliers in data.

Parameters:

  • data – Input data array

  • method – Detection method (‘iqr’, ‘zscore’, ‘modified_zscore’)

  • threshold – Threshold for outlier detection

Returns:

Boolean array indicating outliers

utilities.data_utils.smooth_data(data: <MagicMock id='1744478568528'>, window_size: int = 5, method: str = 'moving_average') → <MagicMock id='1744478568864'>[source]

Smooth data using various methods.

Parameters:

  • data – Input data array

  • window_size – Size of smoothing window

  • method – Smoothing method (‘moving_average’, ‘savgol’, ‘exponential’)

Returns:

Smoothed data array

utilities.data_utils.calculate_statistics(data: <MagicMock id='1744480069888'>) → Dict[str, float][source]

Calculate basic statistics for data.

Parameters:

data – Input data array

Returns:

Dictionary with statistical measures

Calculate skewness of data.

utilities.data_utils.calculate_kurtosis(data: <MagicMock id='1744480062160'>) → float[source]

Calculate kurtosis of data.

Quick Usage

PID Controller Tuning:

from utilities.control_utils import tune_pid

# Define process model parameters
model_params = {
    'K': 2.0,    # Process gain
    'tau': 5.0,  # Time constant
    'theta': 1.0 # Dead time
}

# Auto-tune PID controller
pid_params = tune_pid(
    model_params,
    method='ziegler_nichols',
    controller_type='PID'
)

print(f"Kp = {pid_params['Kp']:.3f}")
print(f"Ki = {pid_params['Ki']:.3f}")
print(f"Kd = {pid_params['Kd']:.3f}")

Process Linearization:

from utilities.control_utils import linearize
import numpy as np

# Define nonlinear model
def reactor_model(x, u):
    T, Ca = x
    Tc = u[0]
    # Reactor dynamics
    dT_dt = 0.1 * (Tc - T) + 0.5 * Ca
    dCa_dt = -0.2 * Ca * np.exp(-1000/T)
    return np.array([dT_dt, dCa_dt])

# Linearize around operating point
x_ss = np.array([350, 2.0])  # Temperature, Concentration
u_ss = np.array([340])       # Coolant temperature

A, B = linearize(reactor_model, x_ss, u_ss)
print("State matrix A:")
print(A)
print("Input matrix B:")
print(B)

Mathematical Utilities:

from utilities.math_utils import numerical_derivative, integrate_ode

# Numerical differentiation
def f(x):
    return x**3 + 2*x**2 - 5*x + 1

df_dx = numerical_derivative(f, x=2.0, method='central')
print(f"df/dx at x=2: {df_dx}")

Data Processing:

from utilities.data_utils import filter_data, resample_data
import numpy as np

# Generate noisy data
t = np.linspace(0, 10, 1000)
signal = np.sin(t) + 0.1 * np.random.randn(len(t))

# Filter data
filtered = filter_data(signal, filter_type='lowpass', cutoff=0.1)

# Resample data
t_new, signal_new = resample_data(t, filtered, new_rate=0.1)
